their eyeballs do not more to extreme sides as compared to our eyes , so hence to compensate that defect they keep their head straight , and also have a better control over the neck .  so to keep eyes stationary at one point irrespective of body position they keep their neck stiff and dont move until required . { i also guess that the camera seems to look like a big "eye" to them which they may consider as a danger and hence keep staring at it constantly , even though u move its body . }

@destinws2 What he said is partly right. Many birds have bad eye movement and a bad vision. If they move their head they only perceive blurred images. To avoid this they try to keep the head as stable as possible as long as they can because only in this position they see clear images. Also the typical nod of the head(which it isnt, its more that the body follows the head) is result of this.

@destinws2 Their eyes may be capable of some slight amount of movement, but not enough to survey the environment. The reason for this is that birds' eyes are not spherical like mammals.
Instead, they must move their entire heads and stabilize it in the same way that we stabilize our eyeballs.

@BirdValiant 
Watch my chicken powered steadicam video and see the eye movement at 36 seconds
Birds can't move their eyes in their sockets, so they need to keep their entire heads stable as humans do with just their eyes. There's your explanation.
@Kinglevel yes Peter!?
This solid head must have something to do with how their brains process flight.

This isn't CGI.  At least if it is CGI it is a masterful job.  The feather detail is great, especially if you consider the tuft of feathers sticking out around 1:06.  The bird is more focused and clearer because it is a different distance to the camera than the others.  If they are using a flip camera, you get a better picture closer up than further back so that would make sense.
